abstract: Identification and characterization of marine natural products with antimicrobial, antioxidant activity with minimal toxicity has received much interest over the past few years. Among, Acropora formosa is one of the unexplored marine organism for the screening of natural products in marine resources. In this study, a novel steroid 2-ethoxycarbonyl-2-β-hydroxy-A-nor-cholest-5-ene-4one (ECHC) was isolated from butanol extracts of A. formosa using vacuum liquid chromatography and sequentially purified by column chromatography. The chemical structure of the compound was elucidated based on spectroscopic analysis including GC-MS, 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR and identified as ECHC. Moreover, in vitro antioxidant activity showed that ECHC was highly scavenged the oxidative stress generative molecules. The in vitro cytotoxic activity of ECHC showed excellent activity against human breast cancer cells. Further, in vivo acute toxicity of ECHC on zebrafish Danio rerio was showed no toxicity as well as no morphological damage was observed after 21 days exposure. Histological analysis revealed that there is no apparent difference was observed between ECHC exposure and control group of D. rerio. Together, these results confirmed that ECHC has in vitro antioxidant and anticancer activity and could be developed as a potential drug against most contagious disease like cancer.

abstract.text: Identification and characterization of marine natural products with antimicrobial, antioxidant activity with minimal toxicity has received much interest over the past few years. Among, Acropora formosa is one of the unexplored marine organism for the screening of natural products in marine resources. In this study, a novel steroid 2-ethoxycarbonyl-2-β-hydroxy-A-nor-cholest-5-ene-4one (ECHC) was isolated from butanol extracts of A. formosa using vacuum liquid chromatography and sequentially purified by column chromatography. The chemical structure of the compound was elucidated based on spectroscopic analysis including GC-MS, 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR and identified as ECHC. Moreover, in vitro antioxidant activity showed that ECHC was highly scavenged the oxidative stress generative molecules. The in vitro cytotoxic activity of ECHC showed excellent activity against human breast cancer cells. Further, in vivo acute toxicity of ECHC on zebrafish Danio rerio was showed no toxicity as well as no morphological damage was observed after 21 days exposure. Histological analysis revealed that there is no apparent difference was observed between ECHC exposure and control group of D. rerio. Together, these results confirmed that ECHC has in vitro antioxidant and anticancer activity and could be developed as a potential drug against most contagious disease like cancer.

body_text.text: Antibiotics have represented virtually the only effective treatment option for bacterial infections. However, their efficacy has been seriously compromised by over-use and misuse which have led to the emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria against many commonly used antibiotics [1] . To compete with antibiotic-resistant bacteria, the researchers focusing on natural products to develop new and novel bioactive compounds. Natural products are major sources of antibiotics and other medicines, but finding new antibiotic substances are difficult challenges [2] . Though, marine resources are trendsetters for discovering the new compounds and the recent research also focusing on marine resources than terrestrial.

There have been numerous studies of the antimicrobials from marine algae, sponges, ascidians, mollusks, gorgonians and soft corals [3] , but there are very few equivalent studies on hard corals (Order: Scleractinia). The presence of antimicrobials in corals to facilitate their survival in competitive environments was studied about 50 years ago and the antimicrobials of soft corals have been well documented [4] .

However, scleractinian corals are the majority of coral reefs, but their antimicrobial compounds have been comparatively less studied. These compounds are generally classified as structural because the interactions are mediated by structures, but they also involve chemical mechanisms [5] . Indeed, the possibility of hard corals engage in chemically mediated interactions either among themselves or towards other reef organisms has been proposed by several authors [6] and there is preliminary chemical evidence for the secretion of bioactive compounds by scleractinian coral [7] .

Biologically active compounds present in scleractinians can affect the cardiovascular and central nervous systems of terrestrial mammals [8] , especially, Stolonidiol, a marine diterpenoid derived from Japanese soft coral Clavularia sp. has potent choline acetyltransferase inducible activity in primary cultured basal forebrain cells and clonal septal cells [9] . However, the activity of these compounds against human clinical pathogens and its significance is not clear. Apart from the previous study [10] , where an unknown number of scleractinians were tested for activity against bacteria, human pathogens have not been used to assess the antimicrobial activity of bioactive compounds. Since human https://doi.org/10.1016/j.steroids.2018.08.007 Received 19 July 2018; Received in revised form 20 August 2018; Accepted 21 August 2018 pathogens are ubiquitous and can have detrimental effects on corals is important to understand. Previously, we reported that steroid derived from Acropora formosa induces oxidative stress and p53-mediated intrinsic apoptosis in human lung cancer cells [11] .

Although most commercial bioactive compounds are not intended to be biologically active, many have reported unintended biological activity that leads to a wide range of human health and toxicological impacts [12] . Zebrafish have emerged as powerful human models for drug discovery and biosafety studies because they develop most of the organs found in mammals including nervous, digestive, reproductive, immune, excretory and cardiovascular systems [13] . Zebrafish have a few unique advantages and features that indicate zebrafish is a simple, cost-effective, and faithful model for both drug discovery and toxicological studies [14] . In this background, the aim of the present study is to determine the antimicrobial activity of scleractinian corals extracts against human clinical pathogens. The purified compound was identified using various spectroscopic techniques and in vitro antioxidant activity was assessed. Further, and in vivo acute toxicity was evaluated against zebrafish Danio rerio.

Three individuals of healthy A. formosa (Order: Scleractinia) was collected from fisherman net at the seashore of Keelakarai, Southeast Coast of India (Latitude 9.230157 and Longitude 78.785454). For each species at least 4-6 gm weight and 2-4 cm length were collected and washed three times with natural seawater. After washed again with artificial seawater, samples were stored and transported to the laboratory for further analysis. The procedure for DNA extraction from Scleractinia corals was followed by previous method [15] . For PCR amplification, primers Acf (5′-ACCGATCGAACGGTTTAG -3′) and Acr ( 5′-ACGCTCCCTTCCAAGAGA -3′) a fragment of mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit 1, ranging between 950 and 1200 bp was amplified and sequenced. The sequences were submitted to NCBI database (JN202443).
body_text.section: Collection and identification of Scleractinia coral

body_text.text: Samples were air-dried for 2 h, following branch tips were chopped into small pieces and powdered. 1 gm of powder was dissolved in 100 mL of 10 different polar (ethyl acetate, butanol, ethanol, methanol, acetone and DMSO) and non-polar (hexane, chloroform, diethyl ether and petroleum ether) solvents and kept in the shaker for overnight [16] . The resultant was filtered and used for the antimicrobial activity.

Totally 21 human clinical pathogens (Table 1) were used to determine the antimicrobial activity of coral extracts. About sixteen of pathogens were used for this study was collected from Government Hospital, Tiruchirappalli -024, Tamil Nadu, India and rest of the pathogens were purchased from MTCC culture collection, Chandigarh -160 036, India.

The crude solvent extract was fractionated through solvent partitioning with petroleum ether (PE), Dichloromethane (DCM) and n-butanol as solvent systems against methanol (10-20% H 2 O). The resulting fractions were evaporated and assayed for antimicrobial activity. Subsequent purification of constituent compounds from active DCM phase employed size-exclusion chromatography using Sephadex LH-20 (Pharmacia, NJ, USA), with a 2:1:1 (v/v) PE:Chloroform:MeOH elution. The most active fraction was further fractionated by silica vacuum liquid chromatography (VLC), eluting with solvents of increasing polarity. A similar VLC column was applied to one of the active fractions from previous chromatography column and bioassay-directed fractionation was continued until a purified active antimicrobial compound was successfully isolated [17] .
body_text.section: Fractionation of purified compound from Acropora formosa

body_text.text: The Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrum analysis was carried out to determine the influence of possible biomolecules in the purified fraction that involved in the antimicrobial activity. The FTIR spectra were collected at the resolution of 4 cm −1 in transmission mode range between 4000 and 400 cm −1 using a SAM-AV spectrum (model -Spectrum RXI). The purified fraction was characterized using Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) in Shimadzu QP-2010 Plus with Thermal Desorption System TD 20 instrument at GC column oven temperature 70°C, injector temperature 200°C at spilt mode ratio 40 with a flow rate of 1.51 mL/min. The MS with ion source temp 200°C, interface temp: 260°C, scan range: 40-1000 m/z, event time 0.5 s, solvent cut time: 5 min, MS start time: 5 min, MS end time: 40 min, ionization: EI (−70 ev). The purified fraction was further characterized by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR). About 5 mg of the fraction was dissolved in 5 mL of deuterated DMSO and analysed for 1 H NMR and C NMR using 500 MHz NMR Spectrometer with solid state attachment (CP-MAS) -Bruker Avance III.

The purified compound was further evaluated for its potential in vitro antioxidant activity using various assays. The DPPH (2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) free radical scavenging activity, hydrogen peroxide scavenging activity, hydroxyl radical scavenging activity and the reducing power of ferric chloride of purified compound was evaluated as per the method described previously [18] . All experiments were executed in triplicates and results were presented at the mean.

Proteins are important chemical substances and are responsible for the transport of any drug to the desired target and hence, the study on the interaction of ECHC with bovine serum albumin (BSA) was performed by tryptophan fluorescence quenching experiments [19] . In brief, the substrate BSA (5 µM) was dissolved in phosphate buffer (pH 6.8) and ECHC was dissolved in DMSO:phosphate buffer (1:9) and dilute appropriately with phosphate buffer to acquire required concentrations. Quenching of the emission intensity of tryptophan residues of BSA at 344 nm (excitation wavelength at 295 nm) was monitored using ECHC as quenchers with increasing concentration. The F /F versus [compound] plot was constructed using the fluorescence data taking into account the effect of dilution. Fluorescence measurements were performed using a 1 cm quartz cell on a JASCO F 6500 spectrofluorimeter. yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide) assay method [20] . In brief, cells were cultured in 96 cell plate (1 × 10 4 cells/well) for 24 h to attach the cells on the plate. After attaining the confluence, the cells were treated with different concentrations of ECHC (50-500 µg/mL) and incubated in triplicates for 24 h. Then 100 mL of DMSO was added to dissolve the MTT formazan crystals and the color intensity was measured using a multiplate reader at 570 nm. After treated with ECHC and cisplatin, the MCF7 and HBL100 cells were observed under phase contrast microscope for identification of morphological changes.

The acute toxicity of the ECHC suspension to zebrafish (D. rerio) was tested following previously reported method [18] . In brief, 10 healthy zebrafishes were taken in 2.5 L container with 1.5 L of the test solution containing 1000 µg/L of ECHC. The test solution was changed every h to confirm the concentration. The test solution without ECHC was used as a control group and each treatment was analysed in triplicate under same conditions. The container was kept in an incubator at 26 ± 1°C with a 14/10 light/dark photoperiod. After 21 days of exposure, the experimental fishes were sacrificed and the major organs were dissected out to assess the impact of ECHC toxicity in fish by analyzing histological parameters. All organs were stained with hematoxylin and eosin and analyzed under confocal scanning light microscopy (Carl Zeiss).

Among many marine organisms, corals (Order: Scleractinia) are much unexplored and has novel source of bioactive compounds. Among scleractinian corals, 50% of the species contain potential marine bioactive compounds and almost 21% of corals have been reported to produce bioactive molecules with medicinal applications. Hence in the present study, we investigated the antimicrobial activity of A. formosa and its anticancer activity against human breast cancer.

Totally ten different polar and non-polar solvents were used for extraction of the bioactive compound from A. formosa and assessed for antimicrobial activity against 21 human clinical pathogens. The results showed that ethyl acetate, chloroform, butanol, DMSO and petroleum ether have good antimicrobial activity among tested solvent extracts (Table 2) . Among, butanol extract showed excellent antimicrobial activity against tested pathogens and thus selected for further characterization.
body_text.section: Antimicrobial activity of crude extracts of A. formosa

body_text.text: The crude butanol extract was analysed using VLC for separation of compounds on silica gel using methanol:ethyl acetate:chloroform (4:4:2) solvent system. The separated compounds were purified by column chromatography and tested for antimicrobial activity against selected pathogens. Antimicrobial activity was assessed for collected four fractions and results showed that fraction 2 (F2) has good activity against all pathogens and rest of fractions showed poor antimicrobial activity against few pathogens (Fig. 1) . Fig. 3 . 1 H NMR (a) and 13 C NMR (b) spectrum analysis of fraction 2 obtained from butanol extract of Acropora formosa.

The purified compound from A. formosa was analyzed in FT-IR to find out the possible functional groups which may probably control the antimicrobial activity of the compound. The purified F2 from A. formosa showed the presence of ]CeH bend at 747 cm −1 , CeH aromatics, CeC stretch and C]O stretch at the range of 882, 1408 and cm −1 . Further, a typical alkyne CeH bend, the monosubstituted aromatic ring, the broad and strong CeO stretch and C]C stretch was found at 628, 770, 1245 and 1585 cm −1 and thus are strong correlates with the structure of the compound (Fig. 2a) . These FT-IR results suggested that functional groups present in F2 may possibly induce antimicrobial and anti-oxidant activity.

After functional groups were identified, F2 was further characterized using GC-MS analysis to identify the compounds present in butanol extract of A. formosa. The GC-MS analysis of purified compound showed 14 volatile substances were carefully identified on the basis of their mass spectral properties as compared with NIST database. Among 14 volatile compounds, most abundant Phorbasterones and Anthosterones were obtained at retention value of 27.264 and 28.792 RT respectively which reveals that the identified compound was pure (Fig. 2b) .

The F2 obtained from butanol extracts of A. formosa was further characterized using 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR to elucidate the structure of the compound. The 1 H NMR spectrum of F2 showed hydroxyl groups at the region between δ 13.173 and δ 14.306, aromatic groups in the region between δ 7.294 and 8.435. The four methoxy signal between δ 3.063 and 4.617 and two aromatic methyl group between δ 2.035 and 2.868 in 1 H NMR of F2. Further, H NMR signals, including the isolated germinal signals (δ 2.08 and δ 7.2) assigned to a highly polarized α,βunsaturated cyclopentenone and angular methyl groups (δ 0.73) confirmed the presence of an exocyclic double bond conjugated to the cyclopentanone ring (Fig. 3a) . The 13 C NMR spectrum showed that four carbonyl carbons at 167.23, 166.93, 167.22 and 150.33 ppm bearing with double bonded oxygen, aromatic carbons at the region between 123 ppm, methyl carbon signals were obtained at the region of 39-40 ppm and a close agreement between the chemical shifts of resonances at 131 ppm assigned to the side-chain carbons (Fig. 3b) .

From above characterization via FT-IR, GC-MS, 1 H NMR and C NMR the F2 was identified as 2-ethoxycarbonyl-2-β-hydroxy-A-norcholest-5-ene-4one (ECHC) and molecular formula was C H 44 O 4 (Fig. 4) . This is the first report that ECHC a steroid extracted from hard coral, previously ECHC was isolated from soft coral only.

After identified F2 as ECHC, the proficiency of ECHC in antioxidant activity was evaluated using DPPH radical scavenging activity, Hydrogen peroxide scavenging activity, Hydroxyl radical scavenging activity and Reducing the power of ferric chloride. The increase of oxidative stress is based on free radicals which can have dangerous effects on metabolism and may cause DNA, lipids and proteins and leads to cancer, aging etc. (Fig. 5 ).

The antioxidant activity of the ECHC was investigated by measuring their scavenging effects as hydrogen donors on the DPPH radical and changed into non-radical DPPH. This radical has a characteristic absorbance at 517 nm and exhibits a purple color that tends to disappear when the radical is scavenged by the ECHC. As shown in Fig. 6a , ECHC has DPPH scavenging activity in a dose dependent manner by increasing the concentration from 100 to 1000 µg/mL increases the scavenging of DPPH free radicals. At the high concentration (1000 µg/ mL), the effect of ECHC on DPPH scavenging was 76% and 39% of activity was measured at low concentration (100 µg/mL). These results indicated that ECHC can act as potential DPPH scavenger by donating hydrogen atoms.

The major role of the antioxidant compound is to remove the free radicals responsible for oxidative stress which is assuming an important role in the pathogenesis of specific diseases and aging. In the present study, ECHC demonstrated a moderate H 2 O 2 scavenging activity comparing to commercial antioxidant vitamin C. As shown in Fig. 6b , the higher concentration of ECHC (1000 µg/mL) has only 42% of H 2 O 2 scavenging activity and IC concentration was not able to find out in the tested concentration of ECHC due to its poor scavenging rate of H 2 O 2 Together, these findings showed that ECHC is moderately scavenging ROS inducing molecules and can reduce ROS generation in cells.

Hydroxyl radicals have free access to cell membranes and can cause tissue damage and scavenging of these specific radicals may prevent DNA damage. The dose dependent scavenging effect of ECHC was shown in Fig. 7a and about 60% of hydroxyl radical at 1000 µg/mL and 900 µg/mL were determined as IC 50 . Only 3% of hydroxyl radical was scavenged at 100 µg/mL concentration.

The oxidation and reduction of chloride ions are dynamic antithesis in the body and act as a significant potential index of antioxidant activity. In the present study, the addition of ECHC with ferric chloride could reduce the Fe 3+ to the Fe 2+ was monitored by the formation of Prussian blue at 700 nm. The color formation clearly indicates the reducing power of ECHC by donating electron or hydrogen during the reaction. About 48% of reducing power ability of ECHC was obtained at higher concentration and only 2% was obtained at a lower concentration (Fig. 7b) . Together, these results indicate that the ECHC has moderate reducing power ability compared to commercial antioxidant vitamin C.

The interaction of BSA with ECHC was investigated by fluorescence emission at room temperature by Stern-Volmer relation. A solution of BSA (1 mM) was added with different concentrations of ECHC (0-500 µg/mL) and the fluorescence spectra was recorded in the range of 300-450 nm upon excitation at 280 nm. The effects of ECHC on the fluorescence emission spectrum of BSA are shown in Fig. 8

Further, different concentration of ECHC was tested for their cytotoxic activity against human breast cancer cell line (MCF7) and normal cell line (HBL100) using MTT assay. As shown in Fig. 9 , the cytotoxic activity of ECHC against MCF7 breast cancer was increased with increasing the concentration and the IC of ECHC was found to be 350 µg/mL. The microscopic analysis of ECHC treated MCF7 cells showed the changes in the cell growth as well as less number of cells compared with control. In other hands, the cytotoxic activity of ECHC against HBL100 normal cells was very less and indicated that ECHC has less toxicity against normal cells (Fig. 10) . The morphology of ECHC treated HBL100 cells showed the similar cell shape and healthy cells compared with control HBL100 cells. As shown in Fig. 11 , the cisplatin increases the cytotoxic activity by increasing the concentration as like as ECHC in MCF7 cells. The microscopic analysis of cisplatin treated MCF7 cells showed the loss of cells, cell detachment and reduced in cell density compared to control MCF7 cells. Together, these results confirmed that ECHC could be a potential anticancer drug in breast cancer treatment.

In the present study, the effect of ECHC on zebrafish was evaluated using acute toxicity assay. After 21 days exposure with ECHC, the mortality of zebrafish was very less in number (5%) indicates ECHC has less toxicity against zebrafish survival. Further, the histopathology of major organs in control and ECHC treated zebrafish were analysed. The results showed that the well-structured hepatocytes in the liver, normal glomerularcapillariae, mesangial cell hypertrophy, Bowman's capsule layers in kidney, without any damage of connective tissues and lumen in the intestine were observed in both control and ECHC exposure zebrafish (Figs. 12 & 13) . Histological study of gills shows a typical structural organization of the primary and secondary lamellae with pillar cells and it consists of central venous sinus, chloride cells in control and ECHC exposure group of D. rerio. Together, these findings suggested that ECHC does not induce any significant morphological changes in zebrafish after 21 days.

Marine organisms are an important source of new bioactive molecules; thus the scientific community worldwide is focusing their efforts on the isolation and characterization of biologically active natural products. A relatively small number of marine organisms studied have already yielded thousands of new chemical compounds; Porifera (class Demospongiae) and Cnidaria (class Anthozoa) being two main sources of new molecules [21] . Moreover, research of species from unexplored geographical sites with a high biological diversity and endemisms, such as species found in tropical regions, can provide novel marine bioactive compounds [22] . Despite the great biodiversity present along the coastline, an important source of potential biologically active compounds, chemical analysis of marine organisms is still incipient. So far, the chemistry of marine natural products has focused on corals, sponges, tunicates and brown algae [23] . The present study reporting that the steroid isolated from Scleractinia coral A. formosa collected in Gulf of Mannar, Southeast Coast of India specifically focusing on their structures and biological activities. Among the 10 different solvent extracts from A. formosa tested for antimicrobial activity against human clinical pathogens, the butanol extract showed good antimicrobial activity against all tested pathogens using agar well diffusion method. The usage of antibiotic disc susceptibility tests or disc-diffusion assays could rapidly identify active metabolites and particularly useful in the initial screening for antimicrobial activity and following activity during chemical purification [24] . Chemicals produced by higher organisms against co-occurring microorganisms may not simply kill or inhibit the growth of the target microorganism but can act selectively against particular phenotypes or characteristics that are expressed by the bacteria [17] . However, Geffen et al. [16] showed that the coral Pocillopora damicornis rapidly release antimicrobial compounds following a mechanical stress. On the other hand, stony corals, as opposed to soft corals, may use non-chemical defences against microorganisms that may include mucus production and sloughing [25] . Extracts of Hawaiian corals exhibited high levels of antibacterial activity, which was selective against different bacterial strains, and varied at the colony, population and species levels [16] .

The butanol extract was further characterized using VLC chromatogram which showed four fractions and the antimicrobial activity assessed and the results indicated that the F2 showed better activity against selected human pathogens than the other fractions. Bioassay-directed fractionation of the crude extract of X. macrospiculata indicated that the antimicrobial activity was due to the presence of a range of compounds of different polarities [17] . Sato et al. [26] reported that the tissue samples of Scleractinia coral were extracted using MeOH and the concentrated extract was subjected to open column chromatography with stepwise elution of aqueous methanol that potent inhibitory activity against B. subtilis was subjected to High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) separation.

In the present study also reveals that the separated and purified F2 subjected to FT-IR, GC-MS and NMR analysis and the results showed that the F2 was identified as 2-ethoxycarbonyl-2-β-hydroxy-A-norcholest-5-ene-4one and the molecular formula is C H 44 O 4 . Masuno et al. [27] reported that the steroid (Phorbasterones) from marine sponge Phorbas amaranthus has germinal signal, unsaturated cyclopentenone and angular methyl groups in its structure. A typical steroid (Anthosterones) isolated from marine sponge Anthoracuata graceae have the chemical shift resonance of methyl protons, methoxy carbons and a side-chain carbons [28] .

The chemical structure of ECHC was confirmed with the previous report [29] where ECHC was isolated from soft coral Dendronephthya sp. The number of metabolites identified in scleractinian corals has been increasing slowly but steadily [30] . Three of the compounds that were already identified in dendrophylliid corals and they are aplysinopsin, 6bromoaplysinopsin and 6-bromo-29-de-N-methylaplysinopsin [31] . A dimer of 6-bromo-29-de-N-methylaplysinopsin has been reported in coral Tubastraea faulkneri [32] and it also contains two cytotoxic compounds that are not related to aplysinopsins-mycalolides C and D [33] . These compounds are distinct from the aplysinopsin-like compounds in their polarity and therefore could not have been responsible for the antimicrobial activity of the methanol-soluble compounds reported [32] . After identification of purified compound obtained from butanol extract of A. formosa through chemical characterization further tested for antioxidant activity using various assays. Reactive oxygen species (ROS), including free radicals, oxygen ions, and peroxides, are implicated in cell damage. The use of DPPH provides an easy, rapid and convenient way to evaluate the antiradical activities of antioxidants independent of sample polarity [34] . Pyrzynska and Pekal [35] reported that the DPPH assay is considered as an easy and useful spectrophotometric method with regards to screening or measuring the antioxidant activity of model compounds. The purified mycosporineglycine obtained from coral Plectropomus leopardus inhibited peroxyl radical-initiated autoxidation of phosphaditylcholine in a concentration-dependent manner [36] . However, in accordance with free radical thermodynamics [37] , the bioactive compounds have a higher oneelectron oxidation potential than the reduction potential of the alkylperoxyl radicals produced by AAPH (2,2-azobis(2-amidinopropane) dihydrochloride) in the initiation and propagation of lipid oxidation.

The present study results were compared with commercial antioxidant vitamin C that indicated the moderate activity was observed when compared with vitamin C. Unlike ascorbic acid and propyl gallate, the in vitro DPPH radical scavenging activity of vitamin C was significantly high [38] . Chukwurah et al. [39] reported that the absorbance of the control sample was low due to the decreasing of phenanthroline-Fe (II) and the addition of antioxidants can prevent phenanthroline-Fe (II) from oxidation by hydrogen peroxide. Compared to the controls, an increased absorbance was observed of which the magnitude corresponding to the concentration of black coral extract (BCE). The antioxidant compounds in BCE could reduce the oxidation of HO, and the absorbance of BCE groups was close to the blank by chelating reaction of Fe 2+ and phenanthroline [40] .

Further, the fluorescence quenching capability of ECHC was investigated against the protein BSA. The fluorescence quenching measurements have been widely used to study the interaction of drug with proteins such as BSA, HSA, lysozyme, etc. [41] . As results show the emission intensity of BSA depends on the degree of exposure of ECHC and the addition of ECHC resulted in the quenching of fluorescence emission suggesting that the complex formed between the ECHC and BSA. The two hydrophobic tryptophan side chains, 134 and 212 of the protein, to polar solvents and on their proximity to specific quenching groups is evident that changes in the protein secondary structure causing changes in tryptophan environment of BSA occur upon binding with the drug [42] . Histopathology is a basic technique in acute toxicity to provide helpful information for identifying the effect of the drug on various organs of experimental animal and its mechanism of injuries due to enhanced sensitivity of histological monitoring compared with other toxicological parameters such as mortality, behaviour and other physiological changes [43] . In the present study, histological parameters were monitored after 21 days exposure with ECHC and result suggested that ECHC may not cause the oxidative damage and morphological changes in major organs of D. rerio due to the potential antioxidant activity of ECHC. Further, the ECHC has excellent cytotoxic activity against MCF7 cancer cells as well as less toxicity against HBL100 normal cells indicates that ECHC could be a potential anticancer agent in breast cancer treatment. In our previous study, we have reported that ECHC induces the ROS generation in A549 lung cancer and activates p53 mediated intrinsic apoptosis pathway [11] .

Butanol is identified as the potential solvent to extract the steroid from the tissue of stony coral A. formosa. The bioactive potential of butanol extracts further undergone VLC chromatography that showed four fractions and F2 has excellent antimicrobial potential than other tested fractions. The F2 was further characterized using FT-IR, GC-MS, NMR and identified as 2-ethoxycarbonyl-2-β-hydroxy-A-nor-cholest-5ene-4one. The antioxidant analysis of purified compound confirmed that the compound has potent scavenger of cancer inducing oxidative molecules such as DPPH, hydrogen peroxide and hydroxyl. Further, ECHC has excellent in vitro cytotoxic activity against MCF7 human breast cancer cells. Acute toxicity of ECHC against D. rerio confirmed that ECHC could not induce oxidative stress as well as morphological changes. These findings may support as evident for developing a novel steroid into cancer research due to its nontoxic.

back_matter.text: The authors gratefully acknowledge the authorities of Bharathidasan University for providing CLSM facility under the DST-PURSE scheme (SR/FT/LS-113/2009).
The authors declare that there is no conflict of interest to disclose.

FIGREF0.text: Anticancer activity 2.8.1. Cell line culture MCF7 NSCLC cell line and HBL100 human normal cell lines were purchased from National Centre for Cell Science (NCCS), Pune, India. The cells were cultured in Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 1% antibiotic (50,000 units/L of penicillin and 50 mg/L of streptomycin), and 5 mM glutamine. Cultures were incubated in tissue culture flasks at 37°C in 5% CO 2 and 95% relative humidity.2.8.2. Cytotoxic activityThe in vitro anticancer activity of ECHC was evaluated against MCF7 cancer and HBL100 normal cell lines by MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-(a) Antimicrobial activity of fractions obtained from butanol extracts through vacuum liquid chromatography against human clinical pathogens and the photographs showed the activity against P. aeruginosa (b), K. pneumoniae (c) and V. cholerae (d).

FIGREF1.text: FTIR (a) and GC-MS (b) analysis of fraction 2 obtained from butanol extract of Acropora formosa.

FIGREF3.text: The schematic representation of the effect of oxidative stress on human health. DPPH scavenging (a) and hydrogen peroxide (b) activity of ECHC obtained from butanol extract of Acropora formosa.

FIGREF4.text: Hydroxyl radical scavenging activity (a) and reducing power (b) capability of ECHC obtained from butanol extract of Acropora formosa. Fluorescence emission spectra of the BSA (1.0 µM) system in the absence and presence of ECHC (a) and Double logarithm plot determining the binding constant of ECHC with BSA (b).

FIGREF5.text: . The addition of the ECHC to the solution of BSA resulted in a significant decrease of the fluorescence intensity of BSA at 350 nm, compared with the initial fluorescence intensity of BSA. Cytotoxic activity of and morphologic analysis of (b & c) ECHC against MCF7 cells after 24 h of treatment using MTT assay (*P > 0.01).

FIGREF6.text: (a) Cytotoxic activity and morphologic analysis (b & c) of ECHC against HBL100 cells after 24 h of treatment.

FIGREF7.text: (a) Cytotoxic activity and phase contrast microscopic analysis (b & c) of cisplatin treated MCF7.

FIGREF8.text: Histological changes in major organs (heart, kidney and liver) of control and ECHC (1000 µg/L) treated Zebrafish D. rerio were evaluated after the 21 days exposure of ECHC. Histological changes in major organs (spleen, intestine and gills) of control and 21 days exposure of ECHC (1000 µg/L) treated Zebrafish D. rerio.
